title: HISTORICAL ROOTS OF CONFLICT AND DEVELOPMENT: FROM PREHISTORY TO THE COLONIZATION EXPERIENCE
descriptions:
Here is a 306-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Historical Roots of Conflict and Development: From Prehistory to the Colonization Experience

This research proposal seeks to investigate the enduring impact of historical factors on conflict and economic development. The project is divided into two interconnected parts. The first part examines the effect of the colonization experience on conflict and economic development in Latin America. By leveraging administrative data on the first colonizers of Latin America between 1492 and 1599, we will analyze the role of human capital and institutions in shaping economic outcomes and conflict patterns. Specifically, we will explore how the town of origin in Spain, occupation, education, and city of arrival in the Americas influenced the development of institutions and human capital, and subsequently, the likelihood of conflict and economic growth.

The second part of the project delves into the long-run dynamics of conflict by constructing a novel dataset on the location of ancient conflicts using archaeological evidence. This analysis will enable us to understand how very old conflicts continue to influence current conflict patterns. By adopting a within-country and long-run approach, this project will provide new insights into the historical roots of conflict and development, shedding light on the persistent effects of initial institutional and human capital conditions. The proposed research has significant implications for our understanding of the dynamics of conflict and development, informing policies aimed at promoting peace and prosperity in regions with a history of conflict and underdevelopment.

Title: Historical Roots of Conflict and Development: From Prehistory to the Colonization Experience

This proposal seeks to investigate the enduring impact of historical factors on conflict and economic development, with a focus on the Latin American experience. The project consists of two interconnected parts. The first part examines the effect of history on conflict and economic development by analyzing administrative data on the first colonizers of Latin America between 1492 and 1599. We will explore how the characteristics of these early settlers, such as their town of origin in Spain, occupation, education, and city of arrival in the Americas, influenced the development of institutions and human capital in the region. This within-country analysis will shed light on the relative importance of institutions versus human capital in shaping economic development and conflict outcomes.

The second part of the project delves into the long-run dynamics of conflict by constructing a novel dataset on the location of ancient conflicts using archaeological evidence. This will enable us to investigate how very old conflicts continue to influence current conflict patterns across various regions. By combining these two approaches, we will gain a deeper understanding of the historical roots of conflict and development, and how they continue to shape contemporary outcomes. Ultimately, this research aims to provide new insights into the complex relationships between history, institutions, human capital, and conflict, with implications for policy interventions aimed at promoting economic development and reducing conflict in Latin America and beyond.
